nodes.text: A lexicon-based sentiment extraction method that uses hand-ranked semantic orientation dictionaries plus linguistic context handling yields robust, accurate, and domain-portable polarity classification
SO-CAL uses dictionaries of words annotated with semantic orientation (polarity and strength) and incorporates intensification and negation handling
Dictionaries were manually created and hand-ranked on a scale from -5 to +5 for adjectives, nouns, verbs, adverbs, plus multiword entries and an adjectival intensifier list

SO-CAL implements linguistic features: negation (polarity shift model), intensifiers as percentage modifiers applied recursively, irrealis blocking, repetition weighting, negative weighting, and XML/text-span weighting
Mechanical Turk experiments (single-word neutral/positive/negative and pairwise strength judgments) were used to validate dictionary rankings and negation/intensifier behavior

SO-CAL with the full dictionaries and features achieved consistently high polarity accuracies across held-out corpora (Epinions1/2, Polarity Movie dataset, Camera corpus) with overall accuracy about 78.7% (full system)
SO-CAL shows cross-domain robustness: on MPQA sentences, MySpace comments, news/blog sentences, and news headlines SO-CAL (excluding texts with no SO words) attains roughly 77–83% accuracy

Ablation and dictionary-replacement experiments show that manually ranked, part-of-speech specific, moderate-size dictionaries combined with SO-CAL features outperform large automatically generated lexicons (Google PMI, SentiWordNet variants, Maryland) in overall polarity classification
Negation implemented as a polarity shift toward the opposite polarity (fixed amount) better matches pragmatic human judgments than a simple polarity flip in many cases

Modeling intensifiers as percentage modifiers (including multiword intensifiers, caps, exclamation marks and discourse but) applied recursively improves handling of degree and interacts correctly with adjectives, verbs, and adverbs
Including nouns, verbs, adverbs, and multiword expressions (not only adjectives) in the dictionaries increases coverage and improves polarity prediction versus adjective-only approaches

Mechanical Turk validation: manual SO dictionary shows higher correspondence with human judgements (about 73.7% MT correspondence on adjectives) than Google PMI (~48.5%) and SentiWordNet (~57.8%), with pairwise/polarity distributions supporting the manual rankings

Limitation: Very large automatically generated dictionaries can introduce noise (coverage is double-edged) and sometimes reduce performance due to ambiguous senses, POS mismatches, and tangential descriptive vocabulary

Conclusion: Lexicon-based sentiment extraction that combines carefully curated multi-POS lexicons with linguistic context handling (negation, intensification, irrealis, weighting) is a robust, domain-portable approach and a strong alternative to domain-dependent statistical classiﬁers
